devdoc.details: Shows how to work with dynamically-sized arrays in Solidity

clearArray().details: Removes all elements from the array

getElement(uint256).details: Gets an element at a specific index

params.index: The position of the element to retrieve (0-based)

returns._0: The value at the specified index

getSum().details: Gets the sum of all elements in the array

returns._0: The sum of all values in the array

isEmpty().details: Checks if the array is empty

returns._0: true if the array has no elements, false otherwise

length().details: Gets the current length of the array

returns._0: The number of elements in the array

popElement().details: Removes the last element from the array

printPopElement().details: Removes and returns the last element from the arrayIMPORTANT: Contains a potential reentrancy-like issue if used improperly       (though not actual reentrancy since it's not calling external contracts)

returns._0: The value that was removed from the end of the array

pushElement(uint256).details: Adds an element to the end of the array

params.item: The uint256 value to add to the array

setElement(uint256,uint256).details: Updates an element at a specific index

params.index: The position of the element to update (0-based)
params.value: The new value to store at the specified index

devdoc.title: Dynamic Array Demonstration

arr(uint256).notice: No size specified in the declaration (contrasts with fixed-size arrays like uint256[4])Public visibility automatically generates a getter functionInitially empty (length = 0)Stored in storage, so modifications persist between transactions

clearArray().notice: Sets the array length to 0, effectively clearing itMore gas efficient than popping all elements individuallyStorage slots are not actually cleared (just marked as unused)

getAllElements().notice: Returns a copy of the current arrayFor large arrays, this can consume significant gasThe returned array is in memory, not storage

getElement(uint256).notice: Demonstrates array element accessReverts if index is out of bounds (>= arr.length)

getSum().notice: Demonstrates iterating through a dynamic arrayGas cost grows with array size (O(n) complexity)Could hit block gas limit for very large arrays

isEmpty().notice: More readable than checking if length == 0

length().notice: For dynamic arrays, length can change with each push/pop operationView function - doesn't modify contract state, no gas cost when called externally

popElement().notice: Uses the pop() method which removes the last element and decreases length by 1Time complexity: O(1)Reverts if called on an empty arrayDoesn't return the removed value (use printPopElement() if you need the value)

printPopElement().notice: Combines the functionality of peek (get last element) and popMore gas efficient than calling length() and arr[length-1] separatelyReverts if called on an empty array

pushElement(uint256).notice: Uses the push() method which appends to the end and increases length by 1Time complexity: O(1) for single element (amortized, as storage may need to be extended)Gas cost increases with array size due to storage expansion costs

setElement(uint256,uint256).notice: Demonstrates modifying array elementsReverts if index is out of bounds (>= arr.length)

userdoc.notice: Dynamic arrays can grow and shrink in size at runtimeUnlike fixed-size arrays, their length is not determined at compile timeUseful when the number of elements is unknown or variable
